questions.assertion: An electromagnet is a temporary magnet.
questions.reason: An electromagnet loses its magnetism when the electric current is switched off.
options: A. Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
B. Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C. A is true but R is false
D. A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: An electromagnet is indeed a temporary magnet because it retains magnetism only when current flows. The reason correctly explains why - it loses magnetism when current stops.

questions.assertion: Soft iron is used as the core of an electromagnet.
questions.reason: Soft iron easily gains and loses magnetism.
options: A. Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
B. Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C. A is true but R is false
D. A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: Soft iron is used as the core because it easily gets magnetized when current flows and quickly loses magnetism when current stops, making it ideal for a controllable temporary magnet.

questions.assertion: Electromagnets are used in cranes to lift heavy loads of iron and steel.
questions.reason: The magnetism of an electromagnet can be switched on and off.
options: A. Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
B. Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C. A is true but R is false
D. A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: Electromagnets are preferred in cranes because they can be switched on to pick up loads and switched off to release them at the desired location.

questions.assertion: Increasing the number of turns of the coil increases the strength of an electromagnet.
questions.reason: Electromagnets are used in bullet trains.
options: A. Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
B. Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C. A is true but R is false
D. A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: Both statements are true but unrelated. The reason (use in bullet trains) does not explain why more turns increase strength.

questions.assertion: The hammer in an electric bell keeps striking repeatedly.
questions.reason: The electric bell works on a make-and-break mechanism.
options: A. Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
B. Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C. A is true but R is false
D. A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: The make-and-break mechanism is exactly why the hammer strikes repeatedly - the circuit keeps completing and breaking, causing continuous striking.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.assertion: Permanent magnets retain their magnetism without any external magnetic field.
questions.reason: Permanent magnets are made of soft materials.
options: A. Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
B. Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C. A is true but R is false
D. A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: The assertion is true - permanent magnets retain magnetism. But the reason is false - permanent magnets are made of hard materials, not soft materials.

questions.assertion: The spring in an electric bell pulls the armature back to its original position.
questions.reason: This helps complete the circuit again after it is broken.
options: A. Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
B. Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C. A is true but R is false
D. A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: When the spring pulls the armature back, it restores contact with the contact screw, completing the circuit again for the next cycle.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.assertion: Electromagnetic induction produces induced current.
questions.reason: Electromagnetic induction requires a constant magnetic field.
options: A. Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
B. Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C. A is true but R is false
D. A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: The assertion is true - induction produces induced current. But the reason is false - induction requires a changing magnetic field, not a constant one.

questions.assertion: The end of an electromagnet where current flows clockwise acts as the south pole.
questions.reason: The end where current flows anticlockwise acts as the north pole.
options: A. Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
B. Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C. A is true but R is false
D. A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: Both statements are true facts about electromagnet poles, but the reason does not explain why clockwise current creates a south pole.

questions.assertion: Insulated copper wire is used to make the coil of an electromagnet.
questions.reason: Insulation prevents short circuit between adjacent turns.
options: A. Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
B. Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C. A is true but R is false
D. A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: Insulated wire is used specifically because insulation prevents short circuits between turns, ensuring current flows through all turns properly.

questions.assertion: Michael Faraday discovered electromagnetic induction in 1831.
questions.reason: Electromagnetic induction requires relative motion between magnet and conductor.
options: A. Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
B. Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C. A is true but R is false
D. A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: Both facts are true - Faraday did discover induction in 1831, and relative motion is required. However, the reason doesn't explain the discovery date.

questions.assertion: A galvanometer is used to detect induced current.
questions.reason: Galvanometers are more sensitive than ammeters.
options: A. Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
B. Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C. A is true but R is false
D. A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: Galvanometers are used for detecting induced current because they are more sensitive and can detect the small currents typically produced in simple induction experiments.

questions.assertion: U-shaped electromagnets are used in electric bells.
questions.reason: U-shaped electromagnets have both poles on the same side.
options: A. Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
B. Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C. A is true but R is false
D. A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: U-shaped electromagnets are preferred in bells because having both poles on the same side creates a concentrated field that attracts the armature more effectively.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.assertion: Electric generators convert mechanical energy to electrical energy.
questions.reason: Generators work on the principle of electromagnetic induction.
options: A. Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
B. Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C. A is true but R is false
D. A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: Generators do convert mechanical to electrical energy, and electromagnetic induction is exactly the principle that enables this conversion.

questions.assertion: Transformers work only with alternating current.
questions.reason: Electromagnetic induction requires a changing magnetic field.
options: A. Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
B. Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C. A is true but R is false
D. A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: Transformers need AC because only changing current creates a changing magnetic field, which is essential for electromagnetic induction to occur in the secondary coil.

questions.assertion: MRI machines use electromagnets instead of permanent magnets.
questions.reason: Permanent magnets are cheaper than electromagnets.
options: A. Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
B. Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C. A is true but R is false
D. A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: MRI machines do use electromagnets (true assertion), but permanent magnets are generally cheaper (false reason). Electromagnets are used because they can create much stronger, controllable fields.

questions.assertion: Maglev trains can achieve very high speeds.
questions.reason: Electromagnets eliminate friction between wheels and rails.
options: A. Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
B. Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C. A is true but R is false
D. A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: Maglev trains achieve high speeds because magnetic levitation eliminates wheel-rail friction, which is a major speed limiter in conventional trains.

questions.assertion: The plastic coating is removed from wire ends when making an electromagnet.
questions.reason: Plastic is an electrical conductor.
options: A. Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
B. Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C. A is true but R is false
D. A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: Coating is removed from ends (true), but plastic is an insulator, not a conductor (false). It's removed so copper can make electrical contact with battery terminals.

questions.assertion: Closely wound coils make stronger electromagnets.
questions.reason: Closely wound coils have more turns per unit length.
options: A. Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
B. Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C. A is true but R is false
D. A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: Both are true and causally related - more turns per unit length means stronger electromagnet, which is exactly what closely wound coils achieve.

questions.assertion: Steel is used as the core of electromagnets.
questions.reason: Steel has low retentivity.
options: A. Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
B. Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C. A is true but R is false
D. A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: The assertion is false - soft iron, not steel, is used. The reason is also incorrect - steel has high retentivity, not low. Soft iron with low retentivity is used.

questions.assertion: The armature in an electric bell is made of iron.
questions.reason: Iron is a magnetic material that can be attracted by electromagnets.
options: A. Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
B. Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C. A is true but R is false
D. A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: The armature is made of iron specifically because it needs to be attracted by the electromagnet for the bell mechanism to work.
questions.source_section: The Electric Bell - Application of Electromagnet

questions.assertion: Paper clips fall off an electromagnet when current stops.
questions.reason: Soft iron has low retentivity.
options: A. Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
B. Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C. A is true but R is false
D. A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: Clips fall off because the soft iron core cannot retain magnetism (low retentivity) when current stops, so there's nothing to attract them.

questions.assertion: Reversing battery connections reverses the poles of an electromagnet.
questions.reason: Current direction determines which end is north or south pole.
options: A. Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
B. Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C. A is true but R is false
D. A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: When battery is reversed, current flows opposite direction. Since polarity depends on current direction (clockwise=south, anticlockwise=north), poles reverse.

questions.assertion: Electric motors convert electrical energy to mechanical energy.
questions.reason: Motors work on the same principle as generators.
options: A. Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
B. Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C. A is true but R is false
D. A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: Motors do convert electrical to mechanical energy (true). However, the reason is partially false - motors work on the reverse principle to generators (magnetic effect of current vs electromagnetic induction).

questions.assertion: A control experiment is needed for a fair test of the electromagnet activity.
questions.reason: We must check if the nail alone picks up paper clips.
options: A. Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
B. Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
C. A is true but R is false
D. A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: For a fair test, we need to confirm that current causes the magnetism. Testing the nail without current (the control) verifies that the nail wasn't already magnetic.
